name: The Great Gatsby
author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
review: A lit dive into the Roaring Twenties. Gatsby throws the wildest parties, but deep down it’s all about chasing lost love. Fitzgerald flexes with poetic vibes that still hit hard today. Classic gem.

name: To Kill a Mockingbird
author: Harper Lee
review: Not just a book, it’s a life lesson wrapped in Southern drama. Atticus is the ultimate moral compass, Scout keeps it real, and the story slaps with truth about justice and empathy.

author: George Orwell
review: Straight-up dystopian chills. Orwell’s vision of Big Brother, thought police, and zero privacy is both wild and way too real. A book that makes you side-eye your Wi-Fi router.

name: The Catcher in the Rye
author: J.D. Salinger
review: Teen angst level: legendary. Holden Caulfield drags you through New York while hating on phonies. If you’ve ever felt lost, this book will feel like your moody bestie.

name: Pride and Prejudice
author: Jane Austen
review: Romance, sass, and sharp clapbacks from 1813. Elizabeth Bennet is a savage in lace, Mr. Darcy is peak brooding energy, and Austen proves wit never goes out of style.

name: The Hobbit
author: J.R.R. Tolkien
review: A cozy start to Middle-earth madness. Bilbo just wants snacks and naps but ends up in an epic quest. Dragons, dwarves, and Tolkien’s worldbuilding = chef’s kiss.

name: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone
author: J.K. Rowling
review: The OG magical starter pack. Wands, owls, Quidditch — pure wizard vibes. The world-building is so good it’ll have you checking the mail for your Hogwarts letter.

name: The Alchemist
author: Paulo Coelho
review: Spiritual glow-up in paperback. Santiago’s journey is all about chasing dreams, finding meaning, and vibing with the universe. Simple but deep — a soul snack.

name: The Girl on the Train
author: Paula Hawkins
review: Dark, twisty, and messy AF. An unreliable narrator plus secrets on secrets make this thriller impossible to put down. Feels like eavesdropping on drama through a foggy window.
